feed.title: Zhe Han
feed.subtitle: This is my personal website. I am a researcher in Computational Mechanics Group, Section of Applied Mechanics, Department of Materials, Mechanics, Management & Design, Faculty of Civil Engineering and Geosciences, TU Delft.

entry.title: Research Project in TU Delft
entry.content:
Computational Micromechanical Model for Tensile Failure in Composites with Fibre-Pullout

Abstract

This work was cooperated with Asscociate Professor Frans van der Meer (Faculty of Civil Engineering and Geosciences, TU Delft) and Assisstant Professor Boyang Chen (Faculty of Aerospace Engineering, TU Delft). My research topic was to develop a Cohesive Element connecting the Beam element and Solid element (beam-solid CE), which can increase the computational efficiency due to fewer degrees of freedom. Two main perspectives can make contributions to the motivation. On the one hand, normally in 3D space, the structural(beam) elements provide fewer degrees of freedom. On the other hand, larger mesh size can be applied due to the higher order continuity of the structural element, leading to fewer degrees of freedom as well. In accordance with the derivation of the beam-solid CE, the Finite Elment Method code was implemented by the open source C++ library Jive. To verify the validity of the beam-solid CE, numerical results were compared with analytical benchmark solutions of the existing literature with respect to Double Cantilever Beam(DCB), End-Notch Flexure(ENF) and Mixed-Mode Bending(MMB) tests.

Motivation for developing the Beam-Solid CE

Schematic of 3D Beam-Solid CE

Schematic of 2D Beam-Solid CE

I. DCB test

Schematic of boundary conditions for DCB test

Comparison of DCB results

II. ENF test

Schematic of boundary conditions for ENF test

Comparison of ENF results

III. MMB test

Schematic of boundary conditions for MMB test

Comparison of MMB results

entry.title: Master Projects Outline
entry.content:
Abstract

My master thesis is Study on the Transient Oxidation of Needle Punched Carbon/Carbon Composites with Multiscale Coupling Method supervised by Prof. C.W. Zhou in Engineering Mechanics department, College of Aerospace Engineering, NUAA. This thesis explored the transient oxidation behaviors of carbon/carbon composites at various scales and their coupling model with the multiscale method.

SEM Image of Oxidation Surface for NP C/C Composites

I. Study on the oxidation and mechanical properties of needle punched carbon/carbon composites with multi-scale coupling method (National Natural Science Foundation of China)

entry.title: Welcome to my website!
entry.content:
🏠 Introduction

  • This website is ONLY used for technology sharing.
  • Contents are mainly about theoretical and computational mechanics and programming technical skills.

👨‍💻 Blogger

  • My name is Zhe Han. I am from China. Now I am a PhD candidate with 4 years contract in Computational Mechanics Group, TU Delft.
  • Before this, from 2012 to 2016, I used to be an undergraduate student ranking first in Civil Engineering department of Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics (NUAA) and I got my Bachelor Degree.
  • After that, during three years 2018-2021, I was a graduate student studied in Engineering Mechanics department of Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics (NUAA). In my final year of this period, I was awarded Chinese National Scholarship and Outstanding Graduate Award, and then I obtained my Master Degree.
  • My master thesis is Study on the Transient Oxidation of Needle Punched Carbon/Carbon Composites with Multiscale Coupling Method supervised by Prof. Chuwei Zhou in Engineering Mechanics department, College of Aerospace Engineering, NUAA. This thesis explored the transient oxidation behaviors of carbon/carbon composites at various scales and their coupling model with the multiscale method.

⛹ Interesting Fields

  • My research focuses on Solid Mechanics and Computational Mechanics of Composite Materials with Multiscale Modeling Strategy.
  • Besides those, I pay attention to the programming skills, though I am still a beginner on that.

📬 Contact

  • If you like contents I shared with you, please follow my website. I will update some technical blogs.
